awd_titl_txt: Conceptual Design Proposal for the 40 T All-Superconducting Magnet
awd_abstract_narration:
This activity is the second year of the 40T Superconducting (SC) Magnet project at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory (NHMFL). It describes high-temperature superconducting (HTS) test magnets and related work necessary to validate technology advances sufficient to complete the conceptual design of a 40T SC magnet. Both a 40T SC magnet and a subsequent 60T Hybrid magnet were listed as national priorities in the 2013 National Research Council report on High Magnetic Field Science and Its Application in the United States. This 40T SC magnet will enable the United States to further and decisively advance its leadership in SC magnets via another great “superconducting leap”, exceeding in magnitude even its recent achievement of 32T in an all-superconducting magnet. Upon its commissioning, the 40T SC magnet will become a flagship in the NHMFL’s suite of high-field magnets that serve its growing user community. The NHMFL presently provides >11,000 days of magnet time annually to >2,000 users, including ~700 Ph.D. students and ~300 postdocs, for high-magnetic-field experiments. This research has resulted in 3,180 refereed papers in the scientific literature from 2012 to 2018. The new magnet will roughly double user access to DC magnetic fields exceeding 36T. The 40T SC magnet will be highly featured in the NHMFL’s education and public outreach programs that interact annually with >10,000 K-12 students via classroom outreach and lab tours and >10,000 visitors of all ages to the NHMFL’s annual Open House. The technology development resulting from the realization of this 40T SC magnet will set a benchmark for high-field magnets connected with frontier capabilities in high energy physics, fusion, X-ray and neutron facilities, nuclear magnetic resonance, and magnetic resonance imaging installations.

The 40T SC magnet will be constructed using REBCO (Rare Earth Barium Copper Oxide) tape conductor similar to that used for the NHMFL’s present world-record 32T SC magnet. However, the 40T SC magnet will feature an approximately ten-fold increase in the stored energy of the HTS coils, which places priority on developing active quench protection and reducing coil volume. Two alternative conductor technologies are thus being pursued: 1) Insulated REBCO (I-REBCO), which exploits comparatively a much better understanding of quench behavior gained from the 32 T SC magnet project; and 2) No-Insulation REBCO (NI-REBCO), which shows potential to attain higher current density and dramatic compaction of coil volume as demonstrated by the NHMFL’s 2017 test of a coil 50mm long and 34mm in diameter that generated a record of a total field of 45.5T in a 31T background magnetic field (generated by an NHMFL resistive magnet). Reliable operation under cyclic loading and during quench are core development goals for both alternatives. The NHMFL developed key insights on quantifying strain due to screening currents in REBCO coils, which opens paths to ensure sufficient fatigue life. Advanced quench protection I-REBCO technology operating at higher current density is underway by exploiting recent improvement in commercial superconductors and super-capacitors. Development in NI-REBCO technology focuses on controlling contact resistance and active quench protection. Either of these developments may be employed in a future 60T hybrid magnet. When complete, the 40T SC magnet will provide a very low noise environment for experiments lasting days at a time, surpassing present-day powered (resistive and hybrid) magnets.  Advances in experimental capabilities will include quadrupolar nuclear magnetic resonance, specific heat, and multi-gate tuning spectroscopies, as well as systematic high pressure measurements and systematic dimensionality crossover studies by repeated sample exfoliation. These frontiers in quantum matter include high temperature superconductivity, Ising superconductivity, re-entrant superconductivity, exciton condensation, non-Abelian quasiparticles, topological matter in its myriad forms, and the mysteries surrounding the Mott transition as the canonical many-body quantum phase transition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF provided funding to the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory (MagLab) to develop the Conceptual Design of a 40T superconducting (SC) magnet between 2019 and 2022. The development of such a magnet system was listed as a national priority in the 2013 National Research Council report on High Magnetic Field Science and Its Application in the United States (MagSci).

The following specific actions were planned as part of this Conceptual Design grant:

1) demonstrate the ability to acquire different grades of superconducting tape (called ?REBCO conductor?) required by a 40T SC magnet;

2) demonstrate that a SC magnet coil that is built with different grades of conductor in different regions of the magnet can be more easiely protected from quench than one using a single grade of conductor. ?Quench? occurs when a portion of the REBCO conductor loses its superconducting properties, such that the entire SC magnet rapidly returns to zero magnetic field. An SC magnet at the MagLab must be protected against damage during a quench in order to be successful as a magnet for MagLab users;

(3) demonstate that magnet coils can be wound with the additional reinforcement required for a 40T SC magnet compared to the MagLab?s world-record 32T SC magnet that is presently available to MagLab?s users;

(4) demonstrate acceptable fatigue life in a magnet coil built from insulated REBCO tape that is operating under repeated strong forces that induce repeated high strains within the magnet coil;

(5) demonstrate an energy storage element for the quench protection system that uses a capacitor-based electrical pulse system instead of a battery bank;

(6) demonstrate the ability to wind REBCO conductor into larger-scale coils than have been previously made; and

(7) develop a production plan for the largest outer coils for a 40T SC magnet.

The 40T team successfully completed the actions identified above, the 40T conceptual design was completed, and the report was submitted to the NSF. A proposal to develop the preliminary and final designs of the SC magnet was submitted to the NSF and funded via the Mid-Scale Research Infrastructure (MS-RI) program. In addition, several postdocs (P. Xu, X. Hu, Y. Oz, H. Yu), graduate students (A. Francis, G. Bradford), and undergraduate students (A. Atallah, A. Cairns, M. Reid, G. Watson), worked on the 40T conceptual design project despite the challenges presented by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Confidence among the 40T team is such that we anticipate submitting a proposal for construction of the 40T SC magnet as an Implementation Grant to the MS-RI program. If funded, the completed magnet will be installed at the MagLab, becoming a flagship in the MagLab's suite of high-field magnets that exist to serve the MagLab?s User Program. The MagLab presently provides >11,000 days of magnet time annually for the high-magnetic-field experiments of >2,000 users from an expanding scientific community. The 40T SC magnet will operate in parallel with the powered magnets, addressing user demand for a new and quiet environment to advance scientific frontiers that require a low-noise environment like that provided by the 32T SC magnet, but at fields up to 40T. The 40T SC magnet will enable advances in experimental capabilities including quadrupolar NMR, specific heat, and multi-gate tuning spectroscopies, as well as systematic high pressure measurements and systematic dimensionality crossover studies by repeated sample exfoliation. These frontiers in quantum matter include high temperature superconductivity, Ising superconductivity, re-entrant superconductivity, exciton condensation, non-Abelian quasiparticles, topological matter in its myriad forms, and the mysteries surrounding the Mott transition as the canonical many-body quantum phase transition.

The 40T SC magnet will be a highly publicized magnet by the MagLab?s education and public outreach programs that interact annually with >10,000 K-12 students via classroom outreach and lab tours and >10,000 visitors of all ages to the MagLab Open House. Scientists and staff mentor undergraduates and teachers via Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and Teachers (RET) programs, and provide research and mentorship opportunities to graduate students, postdocs and early-career scientists. Because the 40T SC magnet will be able to operate virtually non-stop, it will roughly double user access to DC magnetic fields exceeding 36T in the MagLab?s User Program, a user program that presently provides data to ~700 PhD students and ~300 postdocs annually. Finally, the HTS magnet technology development resulting from this conceptual design project will advance next-generation magnets of interest to many other research frontiers, ranging from high energy physics and plasma fusion experiments to X-ray scattering facilities, neutron scattering facilities, nuclear magnetic resonance facilities, and magnetic resonance imaging installations.
